posts.name: Ahmet Selim
posts.cooked:
Hello,

As a rookie team, we wonder if we can use hydrolic pressure rather than pnueamtics? Our mechanical subteam thinks it can be quite more effective.

Thanks,

posts.name: Nathan Shepherd
posts.cooked:
IMG_5490 1170×1079 318 KB Hydraulics are not legal in FRC .

IMG_5490 1170×1079 318 KB

IMG_5490 1170×1079 318 KB

posts.name: Roger
posts.cooked: How about pneumatics, which are legal pending 2025 rules. Just to jump to the next question.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked: You can absolutely use pneumatics as long as you follow the rules about plumbing, pressure, and so on.   The problem with using it in an elevator is that you’d probably need a fairly large cylinder (or multiple cylinders), which means a lot of air, which means a lot of tanks and so on…    There are ways to reduce that (e.g. use constant-force springs to assist with the lifting), but in the end lots of teams have decided that the juice isn’t worth the squeeze.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
I would shy away from pneumatic elevators unless they are lifting small game elements (i.e. 2013/frisbee or 2017 ball).

They can work, but also can be a lot of headache.

Pnumatics are best for linear action in a tight space (grippers, release mechanisms, intake deployment (that has some extra tricks to keep the cylinders safe) etc). It is possible to get multi position control with cimbinations of run-of-the-mill cylinders and some clever plumbing.

Tldr: as a rookie if your elevator is lightweight and moving lightweight game pieces over shortish distances or to deploy a hook then it is ok. Pneumatic elevators for games like 2019 are a lot more involved and tricky.

posts.name: Cooper Surma
posts.cooked: Frankly, I would stay far away from either of those for an elevator, you’re going to have a WAY better time if you just design something based on the COTS designs already out there.  To be fully honest, I would recommend against using any pneumatics at all, pretty much anything they can do can be done more efficiently by a motor, plus a whole lot less headache.

posts.name: Brandon
posts.cooked:
Pneumatics may not be the easiest thing to work with for those who haven’t done it before, but it’s still quite utilized at the highest levels of FRC for a reason. The use cases highlighted in the post above are examples of where pneumatics still make sense, and recent examples include 2056’s 2023 gripper and top roller, 2481’s 2024 gripper and climb, numerous 2019 ball-panel switching intakes and many more.

To be clear, I’d personally try to design around not using pneumatics myself but don’t think it’s fair to say that anything pneumatics can do can be done more efficiently by a motor. Motors can introduce control, weight and packaging complications.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
CooperSurma:

would recommend against using any pneumatics at all, pretty much anything they can do can be done more efficiently by a motor, plus a whole lot less headache.

I really disagree here, in particular I disagree with “pretty much anything they can do can be done more efficiency by a motor”. This is simply not true and a mindset that is treating every problem as a nail that can be hammered by a motor.

@Ben_Martin any thoughts on " problem selection" for peumatics ? I obviously have my opinions here, but you have outstanding competativeness using them in the age of brushless.

posts.name: MrBasse
posts.cooked:
Skyehawk:

any thoughts on " problem selection" for peumatics ?

We have used pneumatics more years than we haven’t.  Our general requirement is to need at least 4 actuations that have to be fast and require only two positions to allow the compressor on the robot.  Less than four actuations often isn’t worth the weight, if you need more than 2 positions a motor is usually easier to implement/control.  I’ve yet to see a year where pneumatics made sense for an elevator without sacrificing another performance criteria.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
Can you provide more information about what you are trying to accomplish with this hypothetical elevator?

Are you going to build this or is it a theorical design?

Does the elevator need to be able to reach multiple different heights or is 2 positions (all the way up/down) sufficient?

Any idea on how much extension you need?

Is this to approach a game task in any specific FRC game?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
For us, pneumatics are a question of “if you need one pneumatic component, can you then use enough components to make it worth it”.

I.e. - pneumatics may make one motion easier, but you need to do a cost/benefit comparison of total weight, and complexity.  Replacing one motion with a pneumatic cyclinder isn’t worth it.  Replacing 5?  Probably worth it.

Another reason to avoid pneumatics and to add into you evaluation is that it’s an entirely second avenue of failures and complexity.

We would have to have a REALLY compelling reason to use pneumatics now-adays.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked:
Im going to stand on the side of pro-pneumatics here.  I’ve used pneumatics on my teams robots every season since 2017 with the exception of this past year (2024) and had a ton of success with it.

Shock absorbing deployable intake mechanisms, gear shifting (not just drive either), and “after the buzzer” climbing are just a few strong examples.

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: I think it really depends on how comfortable/experienced a team is with pneumatics and what they already have on hand to justify them. Using my team as an example, we haven’t used pneumatics a ton in recent years, but have a large stock of pneumatic components so it’s easier to justify. But if I was running a newer team that doesn’t have a stockpile of pneumatics lying around, I would likely want the students to avoid pneumatics unless there’s really good justification for it with all the added complexity.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: Like half the comments in this post aren’t really addressing the OP. Can y’all philosophize about the usefulness of pneumatics in modern FRC elsewhere?

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
Returning to topic:

Hydraulic elevator illegal

Pneumatic elevator bad (probably)

Chain/rope driven elevator better

posts.name: Camren
posts.cooked:
Not to be semantic, but the question was on if it was logical to use Pneumatics which would be a philosophical debate.

Pros:

It would be a fast elevator

For a rookie team it may be easier than a complicated control system

Cons:

heavier

Anything more than 2 positions will require special magnetic cylinders and be more code intensive

It is an extra point of maintenance

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Not to be semantic, but the question was originally on using hydraulics , to which the answer is that any robot using hydraulics* will fail inspection immediately.  The question of whether to use pneumatics instead of hydraulics is a valid one, with a wide variety of answers depending on exact circumstances.

*To be extra semantic, pneumatics are a type of hydraulics that uses air instead of water or hydraulic fluid as the operating fluid… and are legal to use for FRC , more importantly for the question that was asked.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked:
Camren:

Anything more than 2 positions will require special magnetic cylinders and be more code intensive

This is not true. Stacking 2 cylinders can give 4 different positions without any special controls.

And on that note, I’m gonna reject this premise

Camren:

It would be a fast elevator

Because you will end up being severely limited by chocked flow for the inlet of the elevator cylinders because long cylinders that also have a decent force output also require a very large air volume, something you can only send through .25" fittings so fast.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked:
Alex_Y:

Because you will end up being severely limited by chocked flow for the inlet of the elevator cylinders because long cylinders that also have a decent force output also require a very large air volume, something you can only send through .25" fittings so fast.

But there is no limit to the number of actuators that can be utilized in parallel to increase the flow rate.  Another trick includes pivot-locking  the cylinder so the air pressure has already traveled past the solenoid valve, reducing flow choke.  There are so many fascinating ways to use air pressure in FRC !

Facing the criticism of continuing to go off-topic from the original post:  in previous years only air pressure has been allowed per the rules.  It’s unlikely FIRST will be open to allowing other pressurized fluids for robot activation, but the rules have not yet come out for this year’s game.  After all, this is a water-themed game!
